name: Matter and Its Interactions
short_description: Students explore the properties of matter, atomic structure, and how substances interact through chemical and physical changes, establishing foundational understanding of the particulate nature of matter.

sub_topics.name: Structure of Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding atoms, molecules, and the organization of matter at microscopic and macroscopic scales.

sub_topics.name: Atomic Structure Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn about protons, neutrons, electrons, and how atoms form the building blocks of all matter.
example_tasks: Draw and label a diagram of an atom showing the nucleus, protons, neutrons, and electrons in their respective locations
Explain why atoms are electrically neutral despite containing charged particles, using the concept of equal numbers of protons and electrons
Compare and contrast the masses and charges of protons, neutrons, and electrons using a data table
Determine the number of protons, neutrons, and electrons in common elements given their atomic number and mass number

sub_topics.name: Elements and the Periodic Table
sub_topics.short_description: Students explore how elements are organized and identified by their atomic structure and properties.
example_tasks: Use the periodic table to identify the atomic number, symbol, and atomic mass of five different elements
Explain how the atomic number determines an element's identity and position on the periodic table
Classify elements as metals, nonmetals, or metalloids based on their position and properties on the periodic table
Research and present how elements in the same group (column) share similar chemical properties

sub_topics.name: Molecules and Compounds
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how atoms combine to form molecules and compounds with new properties.
example_tasks: Distinguish between elements, compounds, and mixtures using everyday examples like water, salt, and air
Model the formation of water molecules (H₂O) using atom models to show how hydrogen and oxygen combine
Explain why compounds have different properties than the elements that compose them, using table salt (NaCl) as an example
Interpret chemical formulas to determine the types and numbers of atoms present in common compounds like CO₂, H₂O, and C₆H₁₂O₆

sub_topics.name: Properties of Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring physical and chemical properties that characterize and distinguish different types of matter.

sub_topics.name: Physical Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Students identify and measure physical properties such as density, melting point, boiling point, and solubility.
example_tasks: Measure and calculate the density of regular and irregular shaped objects using mass and volume measurements
Design an experiment to determine the melting point of ice and boiling point of water, recording temperature over time
Test the solubility of different substances (salt, sugar, sand) in water and explain the results based on particle interactions
Use physical properties like density, color, and magnetism to identify and separate a mixture of materials

sub_topics.name: Chemical Properties
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding properties that describe how matter changes into new substances through chemical reactions.
example_tasks: Observe and describe evidence of chemical reactions such as color change, gas production, or temperature change in common reactions
Compare flammability of different materials by researching their combustion properties and safety data
Investigate how iron reacts with oxygen to form rust and explain this as a chemical change
Distinguish between physical properties (observable without changing the substance) and chemical properties (observed during a chemical change)

sub_topics.name: States of Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Examining solid, liquid, and gas states and the particle behavior that characterizes each state.
example_tasks: Create particle diagrams showing the arrangement and motion of particles in solids, liquids, and gases
Explain why solids have definite shape and volume, liquids have definite volume but not shape, and gases have neither
Investigate how temperature affects the kinetic energy of particles in different states of matter
Observe and explain phase changes (melting, freezing, evaporation, condensation) using the particle model of matter

sub_topics.name: Physical and Chemical Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between changes that alter the form of matter versus changes that create new substances.

sub_topics.name: Identifying Physical Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing changes in form or state where the substance's chemical identity remains unchanged.
example_tasks: Classify everyday changes (cutting paper, dissolving sugar, breaking glass, melting butter) as physical or chemical changes with justification
Demonstrate that physical changes are often reversible by freezing water, then melting it back to liquid
Observe and record physical changes during phase transitions and explain why the substance remains chemically the same
Separate mixtures using physical methods (filtering, evaporation, magnetism) and explain why these are physical processes

sub_topics.name: Identifying Chemical Changes
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing chemical reactions through evidence such as color change, gas production, and energy changes.
example_tasks: Conduct the vinegar and baking soda reaction, observing and recording evidence of chemical change (gas production, temperature change)
Investigate the rusting of iron and explain how the formation of a new substance (iron oxide) indicates a chemical change
Compare burning wood to cutting wood, explaining why burning is a chemical change and cutting is physical
Analyze whether cooking an egg represents a physical or chemical change by examining changes in protein structure

sub_topics.name: Conservation of Mass in Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that mass is conserved in chemical reactions as atoms are rearranged but not created or destroyed.
example_tasks: Weigh reactants before a chemical reaction and products after, demonstrating that total mass remains constant in a closed system
Explain why a sealed bag containing vinegar and baking soda maintains the same mass before and after mixing
Use particle diagrams to show how atoms are rearranged during a chemical reaction but the total number remains constant
Investigate apparent exceptions (like burning wood losing mass) and explain the role of gas products escaping to the atmosphere

name: Forces and Motion
short_description: Students investigate the relationship between forces and motion, applying Newton's laws to predict and explain the movement of objects in various contexts.

sub_topics.name: Describing Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Using position, distance, displacement, speed, and velocity to accurately describe and measure object motion.

sub_topics.name: Position and Distance
sub_topics.short_description: Students learn to describe an object's location and the distance it travels using reference points and measurements.
example_tasks: Plot the position of a moving object at different time intervals on a coordinate grid using a reference point
Calculate the total distance traveled by a student walking around a rectangular track using measurements of each side
Distinguish between distance (total path length) and displacement (straight-line change in position) for various motion scenarios
Use a motion detector or smartphone app to measure and graph the position of a moving object over time

sub_topics.name: Speed and Velocity
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating and comparing speed as distance per unit time and velocity as speed with direction.
example_tasks: Calculate the speed of a car that travels 150 kilometers in 2 hours using the formula speed = distance/time
Compare the speeds of different animals (cheetah, human, snail) and explain the meaning of the units (m/s, km/h)
Distinguish between speed (scalar) and velocity (vector) by analyzing motion on a circular track where speed is constant but velocity changes
Graph speed versus time for an object moving at constant speed, then interpret the graph to find distance traveled

sub_topics.name: Acceleration
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding acceleration as the rate of change in velocity, including speeding up, slowing down, and changing direction.
example_tasks: Calculate the acceleration of a car that goes from 0 to 30 m/s in 10 seconds using the formula a = Δv/Δt
Identify examples of positive acceleration (speeding up), negative acceleration/deceleration (slowing down), and changing direction
Analyze velocity-time graphs to determine when an object is accelerating, moving at constant velocity, or at rest
Design an experiment to measure the acceleration of a ball rolling down ramps of different slopes

sub_topics.name: Motion Graphs
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting and creating graphs that represent position-time and velocity-time relationships.
example_tasks: Interpret a position-time graph to describe the motion of an object, including when it is stationary and when it is moving
Calculate the slope of a position-time graph to determine the velocity of an object during different time intervals
Create a velocity-time graph for a car that accelerates, moves at constant speed, then decelerates to a stop
Compare position-time and velocity-time graphs for the same motion scenario to understand the relationship between the two representations

sub_topics.name: Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring forces as pushes or pulls that can change an object's motion, including identifying and measuring forces.

sub_topics.name: Types of Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying different forces including gravity, friction, normal force, tension, and applied forces.
example_tasks: Draw and label free-body diagrams showing all forces acting on a book resting on a table (gravity, normal force)
Investigate friction by measuring the force needed to pull objects across surfaces of different roughness (sandpaper, waxed paper, carpet)
Explain how gravity acts as a force pulling objects toward Earth's center and calculate weight using w = mg
Identify and describe the forces acting on a person in an elevator that is accelerating upward, moving at constant velocity, and accelerating downward

sub_topics.name: Balanced Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that balanced forces produce no change in motion (net force = 0), resulting in constant velocity or rest.
example_tasks: Analyze a tug-of-war where both teams pull with equal force and explain why the rope doesn't move (balanced forces)
Calculate net force for objects with multiple forces acting in opposite directions, determining when forces are balanced
Explain why a book resting on a table remains at rest using the concept of balanced forces (gravity and normal force)
Investigate terminal velocity by explaining how a falling skydiver reaches constant speed when air resistance balances gravitational force

sub_topics.name: Unbalanced Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing that unbalanced forces cause acceleration, changing an object's speed or direction (net force ≠ 0).
example_tasks: Predict and test how the motion of a toy car changes when forces are unbalanced (pushing harder, reducing friction)
Calculate net force when multiple forces act on an object and determine the direction of acceleration
Explain why a soccer ball changes direction and speed when kicked (unbalanced force applied)
Design an experiment to show that the greater the unbalanced force on an object, the greater its acceleration

sub_topics.name: Measuring Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Using spring scales and force sensors to measure forces in Newtons and analyzing force relationships.
example_tasks: Use a spring scale to measure the force needed to lift objects of different masses and compare to calculated weights
Measure and compare the force of friction for an object on different surfaces using a force meter
Construct a simple force meter using a rubber band and calibrate it by measuring known masses
Investigate how the angle of a ramp affects the force needed to pull an object up the incline

sub_topics.name: Newton's Laws of Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Applying Newton's three laws to explain and predict the motion of objects in various situations.

sub_topics.name: Newton's First Law (Law of Inertia)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that objects at rest stay at rest and objects in motion stay in motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
example_tasks: Explain why passengers lurch forward when a car suddenly stops, using the concept of inertia
Demonstrate inertia by pulling a tablecloth from under dishes quickly, showing objects tend to remain at rest
Predict and explain the motion of a hockey puck sliding on ice (low friction) versus on carpet (high friction)
Analyze why seatbelts are necessary in vehicles by applying Newton's first law to sudden stops or collisions

sub_topics.name: Newton's Second Law (F = ma)
sub_topics.short_description: Relating force, mass, and acceleration through the equation F = ma and understanding their proportional relationships.
example_tasks: Calculate the force needed to accelerate a 10 kg wagon at 2 m/s² using F = ma
Predict how changing the mass of an object affects its acceleration when the same force is applied
Explain why it's easier to push an empty shopping cart than a full one (same force, different masses)
Design an experiment to verify that acceleration is directly proportional to force and inversely proportional to mass

sub_topics.name: Newton's Third Law (Action-Reaction)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that for every action force there is an equal and opposite reaction force acting on different objects.
example_tasks: Identify action-reaction force pairs when a swimmer pushes against the pool wall (swimmer pushes wall, wall pushes swimmer)
Explain how rockets work by applying Newton's third law to the expulsion of gases and the rocket's motion
Investigate action-reaction pairs when walking by analyzing the force your foot exerts on the ground and vice versa
Demonstrate Newton's third law using balloon rockets and explain the forces involved in propulsion

sub_topics.name: Applying Newton's Laws to Real-World Situations
sub_topics.short_description: Using all three laws together to analyze complex motion scenarios and solve problems.
example_tasks: Analyze the forces and motion involved in a car crash, applying all three of Newton's laws to explain what happens to passengers
Design a safety device (like an airbag or crumple zone) that uses Newton's laws to protect people in vehicles
Explain the motion of a roller coaster through various points on the track using Newton's laws and force diagrams
Solve multi-step problems involving force, mass, acceleration, and multiple objects interacting

sub_topics.name: Gravity and Motion
sub_topics.short_description: Investigating gravitational force and its effects on falling objects and projectile motion.

sub_topics.name: Free Fall and Air Resistance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that all objects fall with the same acceleration (9.8 m/s²) in the absence of air resistance.
example_tasks: Drop objects of different masses simultaneously and observe that they hit the ground at the same time (neglecting air resistance)
Calculate the velocity of a falling object after different time intervals using v = gt (where g = 9.8 m/s²)
Compare the fall of a feather and a coin in regular air versus in a vacuum to demonstrate the effect of air resistance
Explain why a skydiver accelerates initially but then reaches terminal velocity when air resistance equals gravitational force

sub_topics.name: Mass versus Weight
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between mass (amount of matter) and weight (gravitational force) and calculating weight using w = mg.
example_tasks: Explain why your mass stays the same on Earth and the Moon, but your weight changes due to different gravitational forces
Calculate the weight of various objects on Earth using the equation w = mg (where g = 9.8 m/s²)
Compare the weight of a 50 kg person on Earth, the Moon (g = 1.6 m/s²), and Mars (g = 3.7 m/s²)
Design an experiment to measure mass using a balance and weight using a spring scale, demonstrating they measure different properties

sub_topics.name: Projectile Motion Basics
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the curved path of projectiles under the influence of gravity, separating horizontal and vertical motion components.
example_tasks: Sketch and describe the parabolic trajectory of a ball thrown horizontally from a height, identifying where it moves fastest and slowest
Explain why a football thrown at an angle follows a curved path by analyzing the constant horizontal velocity and accelerating vertical velocity
Predict the landing location of a marble rolling off a table at different speeds using concepts of independent horizontal and vertical motion
Compare the paths of projectiles launched at different angles and explain which angle provides the greatest range (45° for maximum range)

name: Types of Interactions
short_description: Students explore different types of forces and interactions that occur between objects, including contact forces and forces at a distance.

sub_topics.name: Contact Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Examining forces that require physical contact between objects, including friction, tension, and normal forces.

sub_topics.name: Friction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding friction as a force that opposes motion between surfaces in contact and its dependence on surface properties.
example_tasks: Measure the force required to drag a block across different surfaces (wood, carpet, tile) to compare friction coefficients
Explain how friction can be both helpful (walking, car brakes) and problematic (machine wear, heat generation)
Investigate factors affecting friction, including surface texture and the normal force between surfaces
Design modifications to increase or decrease friction for specific applications (adding grips, using lubricants)

sub_topics.name: Tension Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the pulling force transmitted through strings, ropes, and cables when pulled tight by forces at each end.
example_tasks: Draw free-body diagrams showing tension forces in a rope used to pull a sled or lift a bucket
Calculate the tension in a rope holding a hanging object at rest using the balance of forces
Investigate how tension changes in a rope when objects are accelerating upward, downward, or at constant velocity
Explain why a rope breaks when the tension exceeds its breaking strength, relating to real-world applications

sub_topics.name: Normal Force
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the perpendicular support force exerted by surfaces on objects in contact with them.
example_tasks: Identify and calculate the normal force on a book lying on a horizontal table (equal to weight if no vertical acceleration)
Analyze how the normal force changes when a person stands in an elevator accelerating up or down
Explain why you feel lighter at the top of a hill when driving fast, relating to changes in normal force
Investigate how the normal force on an object changes when placed on inclined planes of different angles

sub_topics.name: Gravitational Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring gravitational attraction between objects and understanding universal gravitation.

sub_topics.name: Gravitational Attraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that gravity is an attractive force between all objects with mass, stronger for larger masses and shorter distances.
example_tasks: Explain why we notice Earth's gravitational pull on objects but not the gravitational attraction between two books on a table
Compare the strength of gravitational forces between different mass combinations (Earth-Moon, Sun-Earth, person-person)
Describe how gravitational force decreases with distance using examples from space (planets, satellites)
Research and explain how gravitational force depends on both mass and distance using Newton's law of universal gravitation conceptually

sub_topics.name: Weight on Different Planets
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating and comparing weight on different celestial bodies based on their gravitational field strength.
example_tasks: Calculate your weight on different planets (Mars, Jupiter, Venus) given their surface gravity values
Explain why astronauts can jump higher on the Moon than on Earth using gravitational differences
Create a chart comparing the weight of a 50 kg object on all planets in the solar system
Analyze how a planet's mass and radius affect its surface gravity and thus the weight of objects on its surface

sub_topics.name: Orbital Motion and Satellites
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how gravitational force keeps planets, moons, and satellites in orbit around larger bodies.
example_tasks: Explain why satellites remain in orbit around Earth rather than falling down or flying off into space
Describe the relationship between orbital speed and altitude for satellites (higher orbit = slower speed)
Investigate why the Moon orbits Earth and Earth orbits the Sun, relating to gravitational forces and inertia
Analyze the forces on the International Space Station and explain the concept of apparent weightlessness in orbit

sub_topics.name: Electromagnetic Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Introducing electric and magnetic forces as fundamental interactions that act at a distance between charged particles and magnets.

sub_topics.name: Electric Forces Between Charges
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that like charges repel and opposite charges attract with forces that depend on charge amount and distance.
example_tasks: Demonstrate electric forces by rubbing balloons and observing attraction to walls or repulsion between charged balloons
Explain the force interactions between positive and negative charges using diagrams showing attraction and repulsion
Compare electric forces to gravitational forces, noting that electric forces can be attractive or repulsive
Investigate how distance affects electric force strength using charged objects and careful observation

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring attractive and repulsive forces between magnetic poles and between magnets and magnetic materials.
example_tasks: Investigate magnetic forces using bar magnets to demonstrate that like poles repel and opposite poles attract
Map the magnetic field around a bar magnet using iron filings or a compass to visualize force patterns
Test which materials are attracted to magnets (iron, nickel, cobalt) and explain that magnetism is selective
Measure how the force between two magnets changes with distance using a simple experimental setup

sub_topics.name: Electric and Magnetic Force Connection
sub_topics.short_description: Introducing the concept that electric and magnetic forces are related aspects of electromagnetic interaction.
example_tasks: Demonstrate that electric current produces a magnetic field by showing a compass deflection near a current-carrying wire
Explain how electromagnets work by combining electric current with magnetic materials like iron cores
Compare permanent magnets to electromagnets, discussing advantages and applications of each
Investigate the relationship between electricity and magnetism through simple experiments with batteries, wires, and compasses

sub_topics.name: Force Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how forces can act at a distance through gravitational, electric, and magnetic fields.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Introducing fields as regions of space where forces are exerted on objects with specific properties (mass, charge, magnetic poles).
example_tasks: Visualize a gravitational field around Earth by drawing field lines pointing toward the planet's center
Map an electric field around a charged object using arrows to show the direction of force on a positive test charge
Create a visual representation of a magnetic field using compasses arranged around a bar magnet
Compare gravitational, electric, and magnetic fields in terms of what objects they affect and how they exert forces

sub_topics.name: Field Strength and Distance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that field strength decreases with distance from the source and affects the magnitude of forces experienced.
example_tasks: Investigate how gravitational field strength decreases with altitude above Earth's surface, affecting weight
Measure how the magnetic force on a paper clip changes as it is moved farther from a magnet
Explain why Earth's gravitational field is stronger than the Moon's due to Earth's greater mass
Graph the relationship between distance and field strength for gravitational, electric, or magnetic fields

name: Energy
short_description: Students investigate different forms of energy, energy transformations, and the principle of conservation of energy in various systems.

sub_topics.name: Forms of Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and describing various forms of energy including kinetic, potential, thermal, chemical, electrical, and nuclear energy.

sub_topics.name: Kinetic Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that moving objects possess kinetic energy that depends on mass and velocity (KE = ½mv²).
example_tasks: Calculate the kinetic energy of a 5 kg object moving at 10 m/s using the formula KE = ½mv²
Compare the kinetic energies of a car and a bicycle moving at the same speed, explaining the role of mass
Investigate how doubling the speed of an object affects its kinetic energy (quadruples due to velocity squared)
Explain why faster-moving vehicles cause more damage in collisions using the concept of kinetic energy

sub_topics.name: Gravitational Potential Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that objects have potential energy due to their position in a gravitational field (PE = mgh).
example_tasks: Calculate the gravitational potential energy of a 2 kg book placed 3 meters above the ground using PE = mgh
Explain why water stored in an elevated tank has potential energy that can be converted to kinetic energy when released
Compare the potential energies of identical objects at different heights and predict which has more energy
Design a simple experiment to demonstrate that potential energy increases with height using a pendulum or ramp

sub_topics.name: Elastic Potential Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing that stretched or compressed elastic objects store potential energy that can be released.
example_tasks: Demonstrate elastic potential energy by stretching rubber bands or compressing springs and observing energy release
Explain how a bow and arrow system stores and converts elastic potential energy to kinetic energy
Compare the potential energies of springs compressed different amounts and test by measuring projectile distances
Investigate real-world applications of elastic potential energy in trampolines, bungee cords, and shock absorbers

sub_topics.name: Thermal Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding thermal energy as the total kinetic energy of particles in a substance, related to temperature.
example_tasks: Explain the relationship between temperature and the average kinetic energy of particles in a substance
Compare the thermal energy of hot water and cold water of equal mass, relating to particle motion
Investigate heat transfer between objects at different temperatures and explain in terms of energy movement
Describe how thermal energy affects the state of matter, causing phase changes when sufficient energy is added or removed

sub_topics.name: Chemical Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing that energy stored in chemical bonds can be released during chemical reactions.
example_tasks: Identify examples of chemical energy in everyday life (food, batteries, fuels, fireworks)
Explain how food provides energy through chemical reactions in the body that break down nutrients
Compare energy content of different fuels (gasoline, natural gas, coal) and discuss their energy density
Investigate exothermic reactions that release chemical energy as heat and light, such as combustion

sub_topics.name: Electrical Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding energy carried by electric charges moving through conductors and circuits.
example_tasks: Identify devices that use electrical energy and describe what form of energy it is converted to (light, heat, motion, sound)
Explain how electrical energy is transmitted from power plants to homes through power lines
Calculate electrical energy consumption of household appliances using power ratings and time of use
Compare energy efficiency of different types of light bulbs (incandescent, CFL, LED) in terms of electrical energy use

sub_topics.name: Energy Transfer and Transformation
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how energy moves between objects and changes from one form to another in various processes.

sub_topics.name: Energy Transformations
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and describing energy conversions in everyday devices and natural processes.
example_tasks: Trace the energy transformations in a light bulb from electrical energy to light and thermal energy
Diagram the energy changes in a roller coaster from potential energy at the top to kinetic energy at the bottom
Explain the energy transformations in photosynthesis (light energy to chemical energy) and cellular respiration (chemical to other forms)
Analyze energy conversions in a hydroelectric dam from gravitational potential to kinetic to electrical energy

sub_topics.name: Mechanisms of Energy Transfer
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how energy transfers through work, heat, radiation, and wave motion.
example_tasks: Explain how energy transfers when you push a box across the floor (work done by applied force)
Describe energy transfer by heating when a hot object contacts a cold object, causing temperature equalization
Investigate radiative energy transfer from the Sun to Earth and explain how this energy travels through space
Compare conduction, convection, and radiation as mechanisms for thermal energy transfer with examples

sub_topics.name: Energy Efficiency
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that energy transformations are never 100% efficient; some energy is always transferred to less useful forms.
example_tasks: Calculate the efficiency of a device given useful energy output and total energy input using efficiency = (useful output / total input) × 100%
Explain why incandescent bulbs are less efficient than LED bulbs by comparing the amount of energy converted to light versus heat
Investigate why cars convert only about 25-30% of fuel's chemical energy to kinetic energy, with the rest lost as heat
Propose ways to improve energy efficiency in homes or schools (insulation, efficient appliances, renewable energy)

sub_topics.name: Conservation of Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed or transferred, and that total energy in a closed system remains constant.

sub_topics.name: Law of Conservation of Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the principle that the total energy of an isolated system remains constant through all transformations.
example_tasks: Analyze a pendulum swing, showing how energy continually converts between gravitational potential and kinetic energy while total energy stays constant
Calculate the speed of an object at the bottom of a ramp by equating initial potential energy to final kinetic energy
Explain why a bouncing ball doesn't return to its original height, accounting for energy transferred to surroundings (sound, heat, air resistance)
Use energy conservation to predict the behavior of a roller coaster at various points along its track

sub_topics.name: Energy in Open and Closed Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between systems where energy is conserved within the system versus systems that exchange energy with surroundings.
example_tasks: Classify everyday scenarios as open or closed energy systems and justify your classification
Explain why energy seems to 'disappear' in real-world situations but is actually transferred to the environment (friction producing heat)
Analyze a bouncing ball as an open system where energy transfers to surroundings, reducing mechanical energy over time
Compare ideal frictionless scenarios (closed systems) to real situations where friction and air resistance cause energy loss

sub_topics.name: Energy Conservation Calculations
sub_topics.short_description: Solving problems using energy conservation principles to find unknown velocities, heights, or energies.
example_tasks: Calculate the final velocity of a 3 kg object dropped from 5 meters using conservation of energy (PE initial = KE final)
Determine the height a pendulum must be released from to reach a specific speed at the bottom of its swing
Solve problems involving energy transformation on ramps, finding final speeds given initial heights and masses
Calculate the spring compression needed to launch a projectile to a certain height using elastic and gravitational potential energy

sub_topics.name: Work and Power
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding work as energy transfer through force and displacement, and power as the rate of energy transfer.

sub_topics.name: Work as Energy Transfer
sub_topics.short_description: Defining work as force applied over a distance in the direction of force (W = Fd), transferring energy to objects.
example_tasks: Calculate the work done when a 50 N force pushes a box 10 meters across a floor using W = Fd
Explain why no work is done when you hold a heavy book stationary, despite exerting force (no displacement)
Compare the work done lifting an object straight up versus pulling it up an inclined plane the same vertical height
Investigate situations where forces do positive work (adding energy), negative work (removing energy), or no work

sub_topics.name: Calculating Work in Different Situations
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the work formula to various scenarios including lifting, pushing, pulling, and work against friction.
example_tasks: Calculate the work required to lift a 20 kg object 3 meters vertically against gravity
Determine the work done against friction when pulling a sled 15 meters with a 30 N friction force
Solve problems involving work done at angles, where only the force component parallel to displacement contributes
Compare the work done by different people completing the same task at different speeds (same work, different power)

sub_topics.name: Power as Rate of Energy Transfer
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding power as work done per unit time (P = W/t) or energy transferred per unit time, measured in watts.
example_tasks: Calculate the power output of a person who does 300 J of work in 10 seconds using P = W/t
Compare the power of two students climbing stairs: one takes 5 seconds, the other takes 10 seconds to climb the same height
Explain why a 100-watt light bulb uses more electrical energy per second than a 60-watt bulb
Calculate the power of a motor that lifts a 500 N object 2 meters in 4 seconds, showing work calculation first

sub_topics.name: Simple Machines and Mechanical Advantage
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how simple machines make work easier by changing the force or distance, but not reducing total work.
example_tasks: Explain how a ramp reduces the input force needed to lift an object, though it increases the distance through which force must be applied
Calculate mechanical advantage of a lever using MA = output force / input force, showing how position of fulcrum matters
Investigate pulleys and explain how they can reduce the input force needed to lift heavy objects
Compare work input and work output for a simple machine, showing that ideal machines have work output = work input (accounting for friction in real machines)

name: Waves and Wave Properties
short_description: Students explore the characteristics of waves, how waves transfer energy without transferring matter, and the behaviors of waves including reflection, refraction, and interference.

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding waves as disturbances that transfer energy through matter or space without transferring matter itself.

sub_topics.name: Mechanical and Electromagnetic Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between mechanical waves that require a medium and electromagnetic waves that can travel through vacuum.
example_tasks: Classify examples of waves as mechanical (sound, water, seismic) or electromagnetic (light, radio, X-rays) based on whether they need a medium
Explain why sound cannot travel through the vacuum of space but light can, using the properties of wave types
Demonstrate mechanical waves using a slinky or rope and observe how energy travels while the medium oscillates in place
Research how astronauts communicate in space using radio waves instead of sound waves due to the vacuum environment

sub_topics.name: Transverse and Longitudinal Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing waves based on the direction of particle oscillation relative to wave direction of travel.
example_tasks: Create transverse waves on a rope by moving it up and down perpendicular to the wave direction and label crests and troughs
Demonstrate longitudinal waves using a slinky compressed and stretched parallel to the wave direction, identifying compressions and rarefactions
Classify various waves as transverse (light, water surface waves, waves on strings) or longitudinal (sound, seismic P-waves)
Draw diagrams showing particle motion in both transverse and longitudinal waves and explain the differences

sub_topics.name: Energy Transfer by Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that waves transfer energy from one location to another without permanent displacement of the medium.
example_tasks: Observe a cork floating on water waves and explain why it bobs up and down but doesn't move horizontally with the wave
Explain how ocean waves can transfer enough energy to erode coastlines and move sand without the water traveling across the ocean
Calculate or estimate the energy carried by waves based on amplitude, relating larger waves to greater energy transfer
Investigate how earthquake waves transfer destructive energy through Earth's crust causing damage at distant locations

sub_topics.name: Wave Characteristics and Measurements
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying and measuring wave properties including wavelength, frequency, amplitude, and speed.

sub_topics.name: Wavelength
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring the distance between consecutive corresponding points on a wave, such as crest to crest or compression to compression.
example_tasks: Measure the wavelength of waves on a rope or spring by determining the distance between consecutive crests
Identify wavelength on diagrams of transverse and longitudinal waves, labeling the appropriate distance
Compare wavelengths of different waves and predict how this affects their properties and behavior
Explain why radio waves have much longer wavelengths than visible light using the electromagnetic spectrum

sub_topics.name: Frequency and Period
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding frequency as the number of wave cycles per second (measured in Hertz) and period as the time for one complete cycle.
example_tasks: Calculate frequency by counting the number of wave crests passing a point in one second and express in Hertz (Hz)
Determine the period of a wave given its frequency using T = 1/f, understanding their inverse relationship
Compare high-frequency waves (many oscillations per second) to low-frequency waves and relate to energy
Measure the frequency of a pendulum or vibrating object by timing multiple oscillations and calculating cycles per second

sub_topics.name: Amplitude
sub_topics.short_description: Measuring the maximum displacement of particles from equilibrium position, relating amplitude to wave energy and intensity.
example_tasks: Measure amplitude on wave diagrams as the distance from equilibrium to crest (or trough) for transverse waves
Investigate how amplitude affects wave energy by comparing gentle and vigorous wave generation on a rope
Explain the relationship between amplitude and loudness for sound waves or brightness for light waves
Create waves with different amplitudes and observe how larger amplitudes transfer more energy to objects

sub_topics.name: Wave Speed
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating wave speed using the relationship v = fλ (speed = frequency × wavelength).
example_tasks: Calculate wave speed given frequency and wavelength using the equation v = fλ
Measure the speed of a wave pulse traveling along a rope or slinky by timing its travel over a known distance
Explain why wave speed depends on the medium properties (tension, density, temperature) rather than frequency or amplitude
Solve problems involving the wave equation, finding unknown values when two of the three variables are given

sub_topics.name: Wave Behaviors and Interactions
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring how waves interact with boundaries, other waves, and different media through reflection, refraction, diffraction, and interference.

sub_topics.name: Wave Reflection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that waves bounce back when encountering a boundary, following the law of reflection (angle of incidence = angle of reflection).
example_tasks: Demonstrate wave reflection by sending pulses down a rope attached to a fixed end and observing the inverted reflected pulse
Apply the law of reflection to predict the path of reflected waves using diagrams with incident and reflected rays
Investigate how echoes are produced by sound wave reflection from hard surfaces like walls or cliffs
Explain why you see your reflection in a mirror using the principle of light wave reflection

sub_topics.name: Wave Refraction
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the bending of waves when they pass from one medium to another due to speed changes.
example_tasks: Observe water waves in a ripple tank changing direction when passing from deep to shallow water, explaining the speed change
Explain why a pencil appears bent when partially submerged in water using light refraction at the water-air boundary
Predict the direction waves will bend when entering a medium where they travel faster or slower
Investigate how ocean waves approach shore nearly parallel to the beach due to refraction in varying water depths

sub_topics.name: Wave Diffraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how waves bend around obstacles and spread through openings, with greater diffraction for longer wavelengths.
example_tasks: Demonstrate diffraction by creating water waves passing through openings of different sizes in a barrier
Explain why you can hear someone around a corner even though you cannot see them, using sound wave diffraction
Investigate how the size of an opening relative to wavelength affects the amount of diffraction observed
Compare diffraction of different wavelength waves and explain why radio waves diffract more than light waves around buildings

sub_topics.name: Wave Interference
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing constructive and destructive interference when two or more waves overlap in the same space.
example_tasks: Create two wave pulses traveling toward each other on a rope and observe constructive interference (larger amplitude) when they meet
Demonstrate destructive interference where two pulses cancel each other when one is inverted relative to the other
Explain how noise-canceling headphones work by producing sound waves that destructively interfere with ambient noise
Investigate interference patterns created by two point sources generating waves in a ripple tank, identifying nodes and antinodes

sub_topics.name: Standing Waves and Resonance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding standing waves formed by interference of waves reflecting back and forth, creating nodes and antinodes.
example_tasks: Create standing waves on a rope or string by shaking it at specific frequencies, observing nodes (no motion) and antinodes (maximum motion)
Explain how musical instruments like guitars and violins produce standing waves on strings to create musical notes
Investigate resonance by finding the natural frequencies at which an object vibrates with maximum amplitude
Analyze standing wave patterns and count the number of nodes and antinodes to determine the harmonic number

name: Sound Waves
short_description: Students investigate sound as a mechanical longitudinal wave, exploring how sound is produced, transmitted, and detected, along with properties like pitch and volume.

sub_topics.name: Sound Production and Transmission
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how vibrating objects produce sound waves that travel through material media.

sub_topics.name: Vibrations Produce Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing that all sounds originate from vibrating objects that create compressions and rarefactions in the surrounding medium.
example_tasks: Observe and feel vibrations of a tuning fork, drum, or guitar string when producing sound, then stop the vibration to stop the sound
Explain how vocal cords vibrate to produce speech and singing, creating sound waves in air
Investigate different vibrating objects (ruler on desk edge, rubber band, speaker cone) and relate vibration to sound production
Demonstrate that sound stops when vibration stops by damping a vibrating object with your hand

sub_topics.name: Sound Requires a Medium
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that sound waves need a material medium (solid, liquid, or gas) to travel and cannot propagate through vacuum.
example_tasks: Explain why astronauts cannot hear each other in space without radio communication, using the fact that sound needs a medium
Compare the speed of sound in different media (air: ~343 m/s, water: ~1,500 m/s, steel: ~5,000 m/s) and explain why solids transmit sound faster
Investigate how sound travels through different materials by listening through strings, walls, or water
Demonstrate sound transmission using a cup-and-string telephone to show sound traveling through solid materials

sub_topics.name: Longitudinal Nature of Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing sound as longitudinal waves with compressions and rarefactions parallel to the direction of travel.
example_tasks: Model sound waves using a slinky showing compressions (particles close together) and rarefactions (particles spread apart)
Draw diagrams representing sound waves as pressure variations showing high and low pressure regions
Explain why sound waves are longitudinal rather than transverse, relating to how particles oscillate in gases and liquids
Visualize sound wave compressions and rarefactions using computer simulations or animations

sub_topics.name: Properties of Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring the characteristics of sound including pitch, loudness, and timbre, and how they relate to wave properties.

sub_topics.name: Pitch and Frequency
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that pitch is determined by frequency, with higher frequencies producing higher-pitched sounds.
example_tasks: Compare high-pitched sounds (whistle, violin) to low-pitched sounds (bass drum, tuba) and relate to their vibration frequencies
Investigate how changing string length, tension, or thickness on a guitar affects pitch through frequency changes
Measure frequencies of different musical notes and show that doubling frequency raises pitch by one octave
Explain the human hearing range (approximately 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz) and what sounds fall outside this range (infrasound, ultrasound)

sub_topics.name: Loudness and Amplitude
sub_topics.short_description: Relating loudness to wave amplitude and intensity, measured in decibels (dB).
example_tasks: Demonstrate that louder sounds have greater amplitude by observing larger vibrations in a speaker cone at high volumes
Compare sound intensity levels of different environments (whisper ~30 dB, conversation ~60 dB, rock concert ~110 dB)
Explain why prolonged exposure to loud sounds (>85 dB) can damage hearing and the importance of hearing protection
Investigate how distance from a sound source affects loudness, showing intensity decreases with distance squared

sub_topics.name: Timbre and Sound Quality
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that different sound sources playing the same note can be distinguished by timbre, determined by the mix of frequencies present.
example_tasks: Explain why a piano and a violin playing the same note sound different, relating to their unique harmonic structures
Analyze sound waveforms showing how complex sounds are combinations of fundamental frequencies and overtones
Compare pure tones (single frequency like a tuning fork) to complex sounds with multiple frequencies
Investigate how the shape and material of instruments affect their characteristic timbre

sub_topics.name: Sound Wave Behaviors
sub_topics.short_description: Applying wave behaviors specifically to sound, including echoes, resonance, and the Doppler effect.

sub_topics.name: Echoes and Sound Reflection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding echoes as reflected sound waves and their applications in echolocation and sonar.
example_tasks: Calculate the distance to a reflecting surface using echo time and the speed of sound (distance = speed × time / 2)
Explain how bats use echolocation by emitting ultrasonic sounds and detecting echoes to navigate and find prey
Investigate how sonar systems use sound reflection to map the ocean floor or detect underwater objects
Demonstrate echoes in large empty rooms or outdoor spaces and explain why soft furnishings reduce echoes through absorption

sub_topics.name: Resonance and Natural Frequency
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how objects vibrate at natural frequencies and resonate when driven at matching frequencies.
example_tasks: Demonstrate resonance using tuning forks of the same frequency, showing one can cause another to vibrate sympathetically
Explain how musical instruments use resonance in sound boxes or air columns to amplify sound
Investigate the natural frequency of a pendulum or spring and show maximum amplitude oscillation at resonance
Research examples of destructive resonance, such as bridge collapse from wind or marching soldiers breaking step

sub_topics.name: Doppler Effect
sub_topics.short_description: Observing and explaining the change in perceived frequency when the source or observer is moving.
example_tasks: Describe the Doppler effect experienced when an ambulance siren passes by, explaining the pitch change from high to low
Explain why the observed frequency increases when a sound source moves toward you and decreases when moving away
Investigate applications of the Doppler effect in radar speed detection and medical ultrasound imaging
Predict whether pitch will increase or decrease in various scenarios involving moving sources or observers

sub_topics.name: Applications of Sound
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring practical applications of sound in technology, medicine, and communication.

sub_topics.name: Ultrasound Technology
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding uses of ultrasound (frequencies above 20,000 Hz) in medical imaging, industrial testing, and cleaning.
example_tasks: Explain how ultrasound imaging works by sending high-frequency sound waves into the body and detecting reflections from tissues
Research how ultrasound is used in prenatal imaging to visualize developing fetuses safely without radiation
Investigate industrial applications of ultrasound for detecting cracks or flaws in materials through non-destructive testing
Describe how ultrasonic cleaners use high-frequency vibrations to remove dirt from jewelry or dental instruments

sub_topics.name: Sound Recording and Reproduction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how sound can be captured, stored, and reproduced using microphones, speakers, and digital technology.
example_tasks: Explain how microphones convert sound waves into electrical signals and speakers convert electrical signals back to sound
Compare analog sound recording (vinyl records, cassette tapes) to digital recording (CDs, MP3s) in terms of how sound is stored
Investigate how digital audio samples sound waves at high frequencies to accurately reproduce the original sound
Trace the energy transformations in sound recording and playback systems from mechanical to electrical to mechanical energy

sub_topics.name: Noise Control and Soundproofing
sub_topics.short_description: Applying understanding of sound transmission and absorption to reduce unwanted noise.
example_tasks: Design soundproofing solutions for a room using materials that absorb or block sound waves effectively
Explain how noise-canceling technology uses destructive interference to reduce unwanted sounds
Investigate which materials are best at absorbing sound (foam, fabric, cork) versus reflecting sound (hard surfaces)
Research noise pollution in urban environments and propose solutions based on sound wave properties

name: Light and Electromagnetic Radiation
short_description: Students explore light as an electromagnetic wave, investigating the electromagnetic spectrum, wave-particle duality, and the behavior of light including speed, transmission, and absorption.

sub_topics.name: Nature of Light
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding light as electromagnetic radiation that can travel through vacuum and exhibits both wave and particle properties.

sub_topics.name: Light as Electromagnetic Waves
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing light as transverse electromagnetic waves consisting of oscillating electric and magnetic fields.
example_tasks: Explain how light differs from sound, emphasizing that light can travel through vacuum while sound cannot
Describe the wave nature of light including wavelength, frequency, and amplitude properties
Investigate how light is produced by accelerating electric charges or electron transitions in atoms
Calculate the speed of light in vacuum (approximately 3.0 × 10⁸ m/s) and explain why this is the maximum speed in the universe

sub_topics.name: The Electromagnetic Spectrum
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring the full range of electromagnetic radiation organized by wavelength and frequency, from radio waves to gamma rays.
example_tasks: Create a diagram of the electromagnetic spectrum showing radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays in order
Compare wavelengths and frequencies across the spectrum, noting that radio waves have long wavelengths and low frequencies while gamma rays have short wavelengths and high frequencies
Identify applications of different regions of the spectrum (radio for communication, infrared for heat detection, X-rays for medical imaging)
Explain why we can only see a small portion of the electromagnetic spectrum (visible light from ~400-700 nm)

sub_topics.name: Visible Light and Color
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that visible light consists of different wavelengths perceived as different colors.
example_tasks: Use a prism to separate white light into its component colors (red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, violet) and explain dispersion
Order the colors of visible light by wavelength from longest (red ~700 nm) to shortest (violet ~400 nm)
Explain why the sky appears blue and sunsets appear red using the scattering of different wavelengths by atmospheric particles
Investigate how rainbows form through refraction and reflection of sunlight in water droplets

sub_topics.name: Light Transmission and Interaction with Matter
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring how light interacts with different materials through transmission, absorption, and reflection.

sub_topics.name: Transparent, Translucent, and Opaque Materials
sub_topics.short_description: Classifying materials based on how they transmit light and understanding the mechanisms behind each property.
example_tasks: Classify materials as transparent (clear glass, air), translucent (frosted glass, wax paper), or opaque (wood, metal) based on light transmission
Explain why transparent materials allow light to pass through with minimal scattering while translucent materials scatter light
Investigate how the thickness of a material affects its transparency by comparing thin and thick samples
Describe the atomic-level mechanisms that determine whether materials are transparent or opaque to visible light

sub_topics.name: Light Absorption and Object Color
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that object color depends on which wavelengths are absorbed and which are reflected or transmitted.
example_tasks: Explain why a red apple appears red: it reflects red wavelengths and absorbs other colors of the visible spectrum
Predict what color an object will appear under different colored lights (e.g., a red shirt under blue light appears black)
Investigate why objects appear black (absorb all wavelengths) or white (reflect all wavelengths)
Use colored filters to demonstrate selective absorption and transmission of specific wavelengths

sub_topics.name: Speed of Light in Different Media
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that light travels at different speeds in different materials, slowest in denser media.
example_tasks: Compare the speed of light in vacuum (3.0 × 10⁸ m/s), air (~99.97% of vacuum speed), water (~75% of vacuum speed), and glass (~67% of vacuum speed)
Explain why light slows down when entering denser media due to interactions with atoms in the material
Calculate the index of refraction for materials using n = c/v where c is speed in vacuum and v is speed in the medium
Relate the change in light speed to refraction and the bending of light at material boundaries

sub_topics.name: Applications of Electromagnetic Radiation
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring practical uses of different regions of the electromagnetic spectrum in technology and everyday life.

sub_topics.name: Radio Waves and Microwaves
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding applications of long-wavelength electromagnetic radiation in communication and heating.
example_tasks: Explain how radio waves are used for broadcasting AM/FM radio, television signals, and cell phone communication
Describe how microwave ovens use electromagnetic radiation to heat food by exciting water molecules
Investigate how radar systems use microwave reflections to detect objects and measure distances
Compare wavelengths and frequencies of radio waves (meters to kilometers) and microwaves (millimeters to centimeters)

sub_topics.name: Infrared Radiation
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring infrared as thermal radiation emitted by warm objects and its detection and applications.
example_tasks: Explain how all objects emit infrared radiation based on their temperature, with hotter objects emitting more
Investigate applications of infrared technology in thermal imaging cameras, remote controls, and night vision devices
Describe how infrared lamps and heaters work by emitting radiation that is absorbed by objects and converted to heat
Measure heat emission using infrared thermometers and compare temperatures of different objects

sub_topics.name: Ultraviolet Radiation
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding UV radiation from the Sun, its effects on living things, and protective measures.
example_tasks: Explain the benefits and dangers of ultraviolet radiation, including vitamin D production and skin damage/cancer risk
Investigate how UV radiation causes fluorescence in certain materials and its use in security features on money
Describe the role of Earth's ozone layer in absorbing harmful UV radiation and protecting life
Test the effectiveness of different sunscreens and materials in blocking UV radiation using UV-sensitive beads

sub_topics.name: X-rays and Gamma Rays
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring high-energy electromagnetic radiation and its applications in medicine and industry despite safety concerns.
example_tasks: Explain how X-rays penetrate soft tissue but are absorbed by bones, making them useful for medical imaging
Describe safety precautions needed when using X-rays and gamma rays due to their ionizing radiation that can damage cells
Investigate how gamma rays are used in cancer treatment (radiation therapy) to destroy tumor cells
Compare the penetrating power of different types of electromagnetic radiation, explaining why X-rays and gamma rays penetrate most materials

name: Optics
short_description: Students investigate the behavior of light through reflection and refraction, exploring mirrors, lenses, and optical instruments.

sub_topics.name: Reflection of Light
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how light bounces off surfaces following the law of reflection and forming images in mirrors.

sub_topics.name: Law of Reflection
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the principle that the angle of incidence equals the angle of reflection for light bouncing off surfaces.
example_tasks: Draw ray diagrams showing incident rays, reflected rays, and normal lines, measuring and verifying that angles are equal
Use mirrors and laser pointers to demonstrate that angle of incidence equals angle of reflection experimentally
Explain why you see your reflection in smooth surfaces (specular reflection) but not in rough surfaces (diffuse reflection)
Predict the path of reflected light rays given different angles of incidence using the law of reflection

sub_topics.name: Plane Mirrors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding image formation in flat mirrors, including virtual image properties and mirror symmetry.
example_tasks: Describe characteristics of images formed by plane mirrors: virtual, upright, same size as object, and equal distance behind mirror
Use ray diagrams to show how plane mirrors create virtual images that cannot be projected on a screen
Explain why your mirror image appears reversed left-to-right but not top-to-bottom
Calculate the minimum height of a plane mirror needed to see your full body and explain using ray tracing

sub_topics.name: Curved Mirrors (Concave and Convex)
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring how concave and convex mirrors form different types of images depending on object position.
example_tasks: Compare concave mirrors (converging, can form real or virtual images) to convex mirrors (diverging, form virtual images only)
Use ray diagrams to locate images formed by concave mirrors at different object distances relative to the focal point
Explain applications of curved mirrors: concave in telescopes and makeup mirrors, convex in security mirrors and side-view car mirrors
Investigate how concave mirrors can focus light to a focal point and produce magnified or diminished images

sub_topics.name: Refraction of Light
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing the bending of light when it passes between materials with different optical densities.

sub_topics.name: Light Refraction and Speed Change
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that light bends when changing media because its speed changes based on optical density.
example_tasks: Observe a pencil appearing bent when placed in water and explain using refraction at the air-water boundary
Predict whether light will bend toward or away from the normal when entering a denser or less dense medium
Investigate refraction using laser pointers and different transparent materials (water, glass, plastic)
Explain why pools appear shallower than they actually are due to refraction of light from the bottom

sub_topics.name: Index of Refraction
sub_topics.short_description: Using the index of refraction to quantify how much light bends when entering different materials.
example_tasks: Calculate the index of refraction using n = c/v where c is the speed of light in vacuum and v is speed in the material
Compare indices of refraction for common materials (air ≈ 1.00, water ≈ 1.33, glass ≈ 1.5, diamond ≈ 2.42)
Explain why materials with higher refractive indices bend light more and slow light more
Use Snell's law qualitatively to predict refraction angles when light passes between materials with different indices

sub_topics.name: Total Internal Reflection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding conditions where light reflects completely at a boundary instead of refracting, and its applications.
example_tasks: Explain how fiber optic cables use total internal reflection to transmit light signals over long distances without loss
Investigate the critical angle for total internal reflection and demonstrate it using a laser in a water-filled tank
Describe how diamonds sparkle due to total internal reflection of light within the gem
Predict when total internal reflection will occur based on angles and refractive indices of materials

sub_topics.name: Lenses and Image Formation
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring how convex and concave lenses refract light to form images with different characteristics.

sub_topics.name: Convex (Converging) Lenses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how convex lenses bend light rays toward a focal point and can form real or virtual images.
example_tasks: Use ray diagrams to show how convex lenses converge parallel light rays to a focal point
Investigate image formation with convex lenses at different object distances, noting when images are real/virtual, magnified/diminished, inverted/upright
Measure the focal length of a convex lens by focusing sunlight to a point or using a distant object
Explain applications of convex lenses in magnifying glasses, cameras, projectors, and correcting farsightedness

sub_topics.name: Concave (Diverging) Lenses
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how concave lenses spread out light rays and always form virtual, diminished images.
example_tasks: Use ray diagrams to show how concave lenses diverge parallel light rays as if coming from a virtual focal point
Compare images formed by concave lenses (always virtual, upright, and diminished) to convex lens images
Explain how concave lenses are used to correct nearsightedness by diverging light before it enters the eye
Investigate the focal length of concave lenses and explain why it is considered negative

sub_topics.name: Thin Lens Equation and Magnification
sub_topics.short_description: Using equations to calculate image distance, focal length, and magnification for thin lenses.
example_tasks: Apply the thin lens equation 1/f = 1/d₀ + 1/dᵢ to calculate unknown image or object distances given focal length
Calculate magnification using M = -dᵢ/d₀ or M = hᵢ/h₀ and interpret positive/negative values
Solve problems involving multiple scenarios to predict image location and characteristics
Verify lens equation calculations experimentally using lenses, light sources, and screens

sub_topics.name: Optical Instruments and the Human Eye
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring how lenses and mirrors are combined in telescopes, microscopes, and cameras, and how the human eye functions.

sub_topics.name: The Human Eye
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the eye as an optical system with a lens that focuses light on the retina to form images.
example_tasks: Label a diagram of the eye showing cornea, lens, pupil, iris, retina, and optic nerve, describing each function
Explain how the eye lens changes shape (accommodation) to focus on objects at different distances
Describe common vision problems: nearsightedness (myopia), farsightedness (hyperopia), and how corrective lenses help
Investigate how the pupil adjusts size in different light conditions to control the amount of light entering the eye

sub_topics.name: Cameras
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing camera operation to the human eye and understanding how aperture, shutter speed, and focal length affect images.
example_tasks: Compare parts of a camera (lens, aperture, image sensor) to parts of the eye (lens, pupil, retina)
Explain how cameras form real, inverted images on a sensor or film, similar to images on the retina
Investigate how focal length affects field of view and magnification in camera lenses
Describe how aperture size affects depth of field and amount of light reaching the sensor

sub_topics.name: Telescopes
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how refracting and reflecting telescopes gather and focus light from distant objects.
example_tasks: Explain the difference between refracting telescopes (use lenses) and reflecting telescopes (use mirrors) to collect light
Describe how telescopes increase the amount of light collected from faint objects and provide magnification
Investigate why larger telescope apertures allow observation of fainter, more distant objects
Research different types of telescopes used in astronomy and their advantages for observing the universe

sub_topics.name: Microscopes
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring how compound microscopes use multiple lenses to magnify small objects for detailed viewing.
example_tasks: Describe how a compound microscope uses an objective lens and eyepiece lens to achieve high magnification
Calculate total magnification by multiplying objective lens magnification by eyepiece lens magnification
Explain the importance of proper lighting and focus when using microscopes to view small specimens
Compare optical microscopes to electron microscopes in terms of magnification limits and applications

name: Static Electricity and Electric Fields
short_description: Students explore electric charge, static electricity phenomena, and how charged objects create electric fields that exert forces on other charges.

sub_topics.name: Electric Charge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the two types of electric charge, how objects become charged, and the conservation of charge.

sub_topics.name: Positive and Negative Charges
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing that there are two types of charge (positive and negative), and that like charges repel while opposite charges attract.
example_tasks: Demonstrate charge interaction using charged balloons or rods, showing that like charges repel and opposite charges attract
Explain the atomic basis of charge: protons are positive, electrons are negative, and neutrons are neutral
Predict the force between various charge combinations (positive-positive, negative-negative, positive-negative)
Investigate why most objects are normally electrically neutral, containing equal numbers of protons and electrons

sub_topics.name: Charging by Friction, Conduction, and Induction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding different methods by which objects can become electrically charged through electron transfer.
example_tasks: Charge objects by friction (rubbing a balloon on hair or wool on plastic) and explain electron transfer between materials
Demonstrate charging by conduction by touching a charged object to a neutral object, transferring charge directly
Show charging by induction where a charged object near a conductor causes charge separation without direct contact
Explain why only electrons move during charging processes, not protons, due to electrons being loosely bound in atoms

sub_topics.name: Conservation of Electric Charge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that electric charge cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred from one object to another.
example_tasks: Explain why rubbing two neutral objects together results in one becoming positive and the other negative with equal magnitude
Calculate the total charge before and after a charging process, demonstrating that it remains constant
Analyze charge transfer scenarios and predict the final charges on objects based on conservation principles
Describe how grounding removes excess charge by allowing electrons to flow to or from the Earth

sub_topics.name: Conductors and Insulators
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between materials that allow charge to flow easily and those that resist charge flow.

sub_topics.name: Electrical Conductors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that conductors contain mobile charge carriers (electrons) that can move freely through the material.
example_tasks: Identify common conductors (metals like copper, aluminum, silver, gold) and explain why metals conduct electricity well
Test materials for conductivity using a simple circuit with a bulb or LED to determine which allow current flow
Explain how free electrons in metals allow charge and electric current to flow easily through conductors
Investigate why touching a charged conductor with your hand discharges it (you provide a path to ground)

sub_topics.name: Electrical Insulators
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing that insulators have tightly bound electrons that do not move freely, preventing charge flow.
example_tasks: Identify common insulators (rubber, plastic, glass, wood, air) and explain their use in electrical safety
Test insulators in circuits to show they do not allow current to flow, unlike conductors
Explain why power cords have plastic insulation around metal wires to prevent electric shock
Describe how insulators can hold static charge better than conductors because charges cannot move to neutralize

sub_topics.name: Semiconductors
sub_topics.short_description: Introducing materials with electrical properties between conductors and insulators, important in modern electronics.
example_tasks: Identify silicon and germanium as common semiconductors used in computer chips and electronic devices
Explain that semiconductors conduct electricity better than insulators but not as well as conductors
Describe how semiconductors can be modified (doped) to control their electrical properties for specific applications
Research the importance of semiconductors in modern technology including computers, smartphones, and solar cells

sub_topics.name: Static Electricity Phenomena
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring everyday examples of static electricity and discharge, including lightning and electric shock.

sub_topics.name: Static Cling and Attraction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how charged objects attract neutral objects and cause static cling through polarization.
example_tasks: Demonstrate static attraction by using a charged balloon to pick up small pieces of paper or attract a stream of water
Explain static cling in laundry using charge separation during tumbling and the attraction between charged fabrics
Describe polarization where a charged object causes charge separation in a neutral object, creating attraction
Investigate how humidity affects static electricity, noting that dry conditions enhance static effects

sub_topics.name: Electric Discharge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how built-up static charge can suddenly flow, creating sparks or shocks.
example_tasks: Explain the shock you feel when touching a doorknob after walking on carpet as rapid discharge of built-up static charge
Demonstrate electric discharge by creating small sparks between charged objects in a dark room
Describe safety concerns with static discharge near flammable gases or in electronics manufacturing
Investigate how anti-static devices and grounding prevent unwanted discharge in sensitive applications

sub_topics.name: Lightning as Electric Discharge
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding lightning as a massive static discharge between clouds and ground or between clouds.
example_tasks: Explain how charge separation occurs in storm clouds through ice crystal collisions, creating regions of positive and negative charge
Describe the lightning process: charge buildup, air ionization, discharge along conducting path, and visible lightning bolt
Calculate the distance to lightning using the time delay between seeing the flash and hearing thunder (sound travels ~340 m/s)
Discuss lightning safety: why to avoid tall objects, open fields, and water, and why cars and buildings with lightning rods are safe

sub_topics.name: Electric Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how charged objects create electric fields in surrounding space that exert forces on other charges.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Electric Field
sub_topics.short_description: Introducing the electric field as a region around a charged object where electric forces are exerted on other charges.
example_tasks: Draw electric field lines around positive and negative point charges, showing direction and field pattern
Explain that electric field lines point away from positive charges and toward negative charges, showing force direction on positive test charges
Visualize electric fields using grass seeds or small pieces of thread suspended in oil around charged objects
Describe how field line density indicates field strength, with lines closer together representing stronger fields

sub_topics.name: Electric Field Strength and Distance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that electric field strength decreases with distance from the charge and depends on charge magnitude.
example_tasks: Investigate how the force on a test charge decreases as it moves farther from a source charge, showing field weakening
Explain why electric fields are stronger near charged objects and weaker farther away
Compare electric field patterns around single charges versus between oppositely charged parallel plates
Predict relative field strengths at different points around charged objects based on field line spacing

sub_topics.name: Uniform Electric Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring the uniform electric field between parallel charged plates and its applications.
example_tasks: Draw parallel electric field lines between oppositely charged parallel plates, showing constant field strength
Explain how charged particles experience constant force in uniform fields, useful for particle acceleration
Describe applications of uniform electric fields in capacitors, cathode ray tubes, and particle accelerators
Compare uniform fields (constant force) to non-uniform fields around point charges (varying force)

name: Current Electricity and Circuits
short_description: Students investigate electric current, voltage, resistance, and circuit components, applying Ohm's law to analyze series and parallel circuits.

sub_topics.name: Electric Current
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding current as the flow of electric charge through conductors, measured in amperes.

sub_topics.name: Definition of Electric Current
sub_topics.short_description: Defining current as the rate of charge flow past a point in a circuit (I = Q/t), measured in amperes (A).
example_tasks: Calculate current when 10 coulombs of charge flows past a point in 5 seconds using I = Q/t
Explain that one ampere equals one coulomb of charge flowing per second
Describe current as the movement of electrons through conductors from negative to positive terminal (electron flow)
Distinguish between conventional current direction (positive to negative) and actual electron flow direction
