sub_topics.name: Direct Current (DC) vs. Alternating Current (AC)
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing DC current that flows in one direction with AC current that periodically reverses direction.
example_tasks: Identify sources of DC current (batteries, solar cells, DC power supplies) and AC current (wall outlets, generators)
Explain that batteries produce DC current flowing steadily in one direction through circuits
Describe how AC current reverses direction periodically, typically 60 times per second (60 Hz) in North America
Compare advantages of DC (portable devices, electronics) and AC (long-distance power transmission, household electricity)

sub_topics.name: Measuring Electric Current
sub_topics.short_description: Using ammeters to measure current and understanding that ammeters must be connected in series.
example_tasks: Connect an ammeter in series in a circuit to measure the current flowing through it
Explain why ammeters must be connected in series (current must flow through the meter) and have very low resistance
Measure currents in different parts of a series circuit, verifying that current is the same throughout
Read ammeter scales correctly, paying attention to range settings and units (mA vs. A)

sub_topics.name: Voltage (Potential Difference)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding voltage as electrical potential energy difference per unit charge, driving current through circuits.

sub_topics.name: Definition of Voltage
sub_topics.short_description: Defining voltage as the energy transferred per unit charge, measured in volts (V = E/Q).
example_tasks: Calculate voltage when 12 joules of energy is transferred by 2 coulombs of charge using V = E/Q
Explain that one volt equals one joule per coulomb, relating voltage to energy transfer
Describe voltage as electrical 'pressure' that pushes charges through a circuit, analogous to water pressure in pipes
Compare voltages of common sources: AAA battery (1.5V), car battery (12V), household outlet (120V in US)

sub_topics.name: Voltage Sources
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring devices that provide voltage to circuits, including batteries, generators, and power supplies.
example_tasks: Identify components of a battery (electrodes and electrolyte) and explain how chemical reactions create voltage
Describe how batteries convert chemical energy to electrical energy, maintaining voltage across terminals
Explain the difference between voltage (energy per charge) and current (rate of charge flow)
Investigate how solar cells convert light energy to electrical energy, producing voltage when illuminated

sub_topics.name: Measuring Voltage
sub_topics.short_description: Using voltmeters to measure potential difference and understanding that voltmeters connect in parallel.
example_tasks: Connect a voltmeter in parallel across a component to measure the voltage drop across it
Explain why voltmeters must be connected in parallel (to measure potential difference between two points) and have very high resistance
Measure voltage across different components in a circuit (batteries, resistors, bulbs)
Verify that voltage drops across components in series add up to the total source voltage

sub_topics.name: Resistance
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding resistance as opposition to current flow, factors affecting resistance, and its measurement.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Resistance
sub_topics.short_description: Defining resistance as the property of materials that opposes current flow, measured in ohms (Ω).
example_tasks: Explain resistance as the opposition to electron flow through a conductor due to collisions with atoms
Compare materials with low resistance (copper wire) to high resistance (nichrome wire, carbon resistors)
Describe how resistance converts electrical energy to thermal energy, causing wires and components to heat up
Investigate why thicker wires have lower resistance than thin wires (more paths for electron flow)

sub_topics.name: Factors Affecting Resistance
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring how material type, length, cross-sectional area, and temperature affect resistance.
example_tasks: Investigate how resistance increases with wire length by measuring current through wires of different lengths
Explain why resistance decreases with larger cross-sectional area (thicker wires allow more current)
Compare resistances of wires made from different materials (copper, aluminum, nichrome) of the same dimensions
Describe how resistance generally increases with temperature as atoms vibrate more, impeding electron flow

sub_topics.name: Resistors in Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding resistors as components designed to provide specific resistance values to control current.
example_tasks: Read resistor color codes to determine resistance values and tolerance ranges
Explain the purpose of resistors in circuits: limiting current, dividing voltage, and protecting components
Investigate fixed resistors versus variable resistors (potentiometers, rheostats) and their applications
Design a circuit using resistors to achieve a desired current or voltage drop

sub_topics.name: Ohm's Law
sub_topics.short_description: Applying the relationship V = IR to calculate voltage, current, and resistance in circuits.

sub_topics.name: Ohm's Law Relationship
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that voltage equals current times resistance (V = IR) for ohmic conductors.
example_tasks: Calculate voltage across a 10 Ω resistor carrying 2 A of current using V = IR
Determine the current through a 6 Ω resistor connected to a 12 V battery using I = V/R
Find the resistance of a component that has 120 V across it and 5 A through it using R = V/I
Solve multi-step problems involving Ohm's law with various combinations of known and unknown quantities

sub_topics.name: Graphing Voltage vs. Current
sub_topics.short_description: Creating and interpreting V-I graphs to visualize Ohm's law and determine resistance from slope.
example_tasks: Plot voltage versus current data for a resistor and observe the linear relationship
Calculate resistance from the slope of a V-I graph, understanding that R = ΔV/ΔI
Compare V-I graphs for different resistances, noting that steeper slopes indicate higher resistance
Distinguish between ohmic materials (linear V-I relationship) and non-ohmic materials (non-linear graphs)

sub_topics.name: Electrical Power
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating power as the rate of energy transfer in circuits using P = IV and related formulas.
example_tasks: Calculate power dissipated by a component using P = IV where P is in watts, I in amperes, V in volts
Derive and use alternative power formulas: P = I²R and P = V²/R using Ohm's law substitutions
Determine energy consumed by an appliance over time using E = Pt (energy = power × time)
Compare power ratings of household appliances and calculate their operating costs based on electricity rates

sub_topics.name: Series Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing circuits where components are connected in a single path with the same current through each component.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Series Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that current is constant throughout series circuits while voltage divides among components.
example_tasks: Explain why the same current flows through all components in a series circuit (only one path available)
Demonstrate that removing or breaking one component in a series circuit stops current in the entire circuit
Measure current at different points in a series circuit to verify it's constant throughout
Describe why holiday lights wired in series all go out when one bulb burns out

sub_topics.name: Voltage Division in Series Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that voltages across components in series add up to the source voltage.
example_tasks: Calculate individual voltage drops across resistors in series using V = IR for each resistor
Verify that the sum of voltage drops across series components equals the battery voltage
Explain why components with higher resistance in series have larger voltage drops
Predict voltage distribution in series circuits with mixed resistor values

sub_topics.name: Total Resistance in Series Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating total resistance as the sum of individual resistances (R_total = R₁ + R₂ + R₃...).
example_tasks: Calculate total resistance of series resistors by adding individual values: R_total = R₁ + R₂ + R₃
Explain why adding resistors in series always increases total resistance and decreases current
Solve problems finding total resistance, then use Ohm's law to find circuit current
Design series circuits with specific total resistance by selecting appropriate resistor combinations

sub_topics.name: Parallel Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing circuits where components are connected across common points with the same voltage across each component.

sub_topics.name: Characteristics of Parallel Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that voltage is constant across parallel branches while current divides among branches.
example_tasks: Explain why all components in parallel experience the same voltage (connected to same two points)
Demonstrate that removing one branch in a parallel circuit doesn't affect current in other branches
Measure voltage across different parallel branches to verify it equals the source voltage
Describe why household circuits are wired in parallel so each device can operate independently

sub_topics.name: Current Division in Parallel Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that total current from the source equals the sum of currents through parallel branches.
example_tasks: Calculate currents through individual parallel branches using Ohm's law (I = V/R for each branch)
Verify that the sum of branch currents equals the total current from the source: I_total = I₁ + I₂ + I₃
Explain why branches with lower resistance carry more current in parallel circuits
Measure and compare currents in different parallel branches and the total current

sub_topics.name: Total Resistance in Parallel Circuits
sub_topics.short_description: Calculating total resistance using the reciprocal formula (1/R_total = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + 1/R₃...).
example_tasks: Calculate total resistance of parallel resistors using 1/R_total = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + 1/R₃
Explain why adding resistors in parallel always decreases total resistance and increases total current
Solve the special case of two equal resistors in parallel (R_total = R/2)
Design parallel circuits to achieve specific total resistance or current values

sub_topics.name: Circuit Components and Diagrams
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying common circuit components, their symbols, and functions in electrical circuits.

sub_topics.name: Standard Circuit Symbols
sub_topics.short_description: Learning to read and draw circuit diagrams using standard symbols for components.
example_tasks: Identify symbols for common components: battery, resistor, bulb, switch, ammeter, voltmeter, wire connections
Draw circuit diagrams from physical setups and vice versa using proper symbols and conventions
Explain the importance of standardized symbols for clear communication in electrical engineering
Practice reading complex circuit diagrams and identifying series and parallel connections

sub_topics.name: Switches and Circuit Control
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how switches control current flow by opening and closing circuits.
example_tasks: Explain how open switches create breaks in circuits preventing current flow, while closed switches complete the path
Design circuits with multiple switches to control different branches or functions
Investigate different switch types: single-pole single-throw (SPST), single-pole double-throw (SPDT), push-button switches
Explain applications of switches in everyday devices for controlling power and functions

sub_topics.name: Fuses and Circuit Breakers
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding safety devices that protect circuits from excessive current that could cause fires or damage.
example_tasks: Explain how fuses contain metal strips that melt when current exceeds safe levels, breaking the circuit
Describe how circuit breakers use electromagnetic mechanisms to trip and open circuits during overcurrent conditions
Compare fuses (must be replaced after breaking) to circuit breakers (can be reset and reused)
Investigate why household electrical panels have circuit breakers rated for specific currents (15A, 20A, etc.)

sub_topics.name: Introduction to Capacitors
sub_topics.short_description: Introducing capacitors as components that store electrical energy in electric fields between charged plates.
example_tasks: Describe the basic structure of a capacitor as two conducting plates separated by an insulator (dielectric)
Explain how capacitors store energy by accumulating opposite charges on the two plates
Investigate how capacitors charge when connected to voltage sources and discharge through resistors
Identify applications of capacitors: camera flashes, power supply smoothing, timing circuits, energy storage

name: Magnetism and Electromagnetism
short_description: Students explore magnetic forces, magnetic fields, the relationship between electricity and magnetism, and applications including electromagnets, motors, and generators.

sub_topics.name: Magnetism and Magnetic Materials
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding magnetic forces, poles, and how magnetic materials interact with magnetic fields.

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Poles and Forces
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that magnets have north and south poles, with like poles repelling and opposite poles attracting.
example_tasks: Demonstrate that like magnetic poles (N-N or S-S) repel while opposite poles (N-S) attract using bar magnets
Explain why you cannot isolate a single magnetic pole; cutting a magnet creates two smaller magnets each with N and S poles
Investigate magnetic force strength by measuring how distance between magnets affects attraction or repulsion
Map the magnetic poles of various magnets using a compass or iron filings

sub_topics.name: Magnetic and Non-magnetic Materials
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying ferromagnetic materials attracted to magnets and understanding temporary versus permanent magnetization.
example_tasks: Test various materials (iron, nickel, cobalt, aluminum, copper, plastic, wood) to determine which are attracted to magnets
Explain that ferromagnetic materials (iron, nickel, cobalt) contain magnetic domains that can align with external fields
Distinguish between temporary magnets (soft iron that loses magnetism) and permanent magnets (hard materials that retain magnetism)
Investigate how heating or striking magnets can weaken their magnetism by disrupting domain alignment

sub_topics.name: Creating Magnets
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding methods to magnetize ferromagnetic materials including stroking and using strong magnetic fields.
example_tasks: Create a temporary magnet by stroking an iron nail repeatedly in one direction with a permanent magnet
Explain the domain theory of magnetism: how magnetic domains align when a material is magnetized
Investigate how strong magnetic fields from electromagnets can be used to magnetize materials
Test the strength of created magnets by counting how many paper clips they can pick up

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Fields
sub_topics.short_description: Visualizing and understanding magnetic fields around magnets and their properties.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Magnetic Field
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding magnetic fields as regions around magnets where magnetic forces are exerted on magnetic materials or other magnets.
example_tasks: Define magnetic field as the region of space around a magnet where magnetic forces can be detected
Map magnetic field patterns using iron filings sprinkled around bar magnets to visualize field lines
Explain that magnetic field lines form closed loops from north pole to south pole outside the magnet
Use compasses to trace magnetic field direction at various points around magnets

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Field Lines and Direction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding conventions for drawing field lines and interpreting their patterns.
example_tasks: Draw magnetic field line patterns for bar magnets, showing lines emerging from N pole and entering S pole
Explain that field line density indicates field strength, with closer lines representing stronger fields
Compare field patterns around single magnets versus interacting magnets (attracting or repelling)
Describe how compass needles align with field lines, with the north end pointing in the field direction

sub_topics.name: Earth's Magnetic Field
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Earth as a giant magnet with a magnetic field that compass needles align with.
example_tasks: Explain how Earth's magnetic field is similar to that of a giant bar magnet with poles near the geographic poles
Describe how compasses work by aligning with Earth's magnetic field to point approximately north
Investigate why Earth's magnetic north pole is actually a magnetic south pole (attracts north end of compass)
Research how animals like birds and sea turtles use Earth's magnetic field for navigation during migration

sub_topics.name: Relationship Between Electricity and Magnetism
sub_topics.short_description: Discovering how electric currents create magnetic fields and how changing magnetic fields induce electric currents.

sub_topics.name: Electric Current Creates Magnetic Field
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding Oersted's discovery that current-carrying wires produce magnetic fields around them.
example_tasks: Demonstrate that a compass needle deflects when brought near a current-carrying wire, proving electric current creates magnetism
Use the right-hand rule to determine the direction of magnetic field around a straight current-carrying wire
Investigate how reversing current direction reverses the magnetic field direction around the wire
Explain the historical significance of Oersted's discovery in linking electricity and magnetism

sub_topics.name: Magnetic Field of Current Loops
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that loops and coils of current-carrying wire create magnetic field patterns similar to bar magnets.
example_tasks: Map the magnetic field around a current loop, showing it resembles a bar magnet with N and S poles
Explain how coiling wire increases magnetic field strength by adding fields from multiple loops
Investigate how increasing current or number of turns in a coil strengthens the magnetic field
Use compasses or iron filings to visualize the field pattern around a current-carrying coil (solenoid)

sub_topics.name: Electromagnets
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electromagnets as temporary magnets created by current in wire coils, often with iron cores.
example_tasks: Build a simple electromagnet by wrapping insulated wire around an iron nail and connecting to a battery
Investigate factors that affect electromagnet strength: current, number of coil turns, core material
Compare electromagnets to permanent magnets, emphasizing that electromagnets can be turned on/off by controlling current
Test electromagnet strength by measuring the mass or number of objects it can lift

sub_topics.name: Electromagnetic Induction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how changing magnetic fields induce electric currents in conductors, the basis for generators.

sub_topics.name: Faraday's Law of Induction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that changing magnetic flux through a coil induces voltage and current in the coil.
example_tasks: Demonstrate induced current by moving a magnet in and out of a coil connected to a galvanometer
Explain that a changing magnetic field, not a static field, is necessary to induce current
Investigate factors affecting induced voltage: speed of motion, magnet strength, number of coil turns
Compare induced current direction when magnet approaches versus moves away from the coil

sub_topics.name: Lenz's Law and Current Direction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that induced current direction opposes the change that caused it, conserving energy.
example_tasks: Use Lenz's law to predict the direction of induced current when a magnet enters or exits a coil
Explain how Lenz's law is a consequence of energy conservation (induced current opposes the motion causing it)
Demonstrate the opposition force by showing that moving a magnet through a coil requires work against induced magnetic field
Apply Lenz's law to various scenarios involving changing magnetic fields and predict current direction

sub_topics.name: Applications of Electromagnetic Induction
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring practical applications including generators, transformers, and induction cooktops.
example_tasks: Explain how electric generators convert mechanical energy to electrical energy using electromagnetic induction
Describe how transformers use mutual induction to step voltage up or down for efficient power transmission
Investigate induction cooktops that use changing magnetic fields to induce currents and heat in cookware
Research wireless charging technology that uses electromagnetic induction to transfer energy without physical connections

sub_topics.name: Electric Motors and Generators
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how motors convert electrical energy to mechanical energy and generators do the reverse.

sub_topics.name: Electric Motors
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how current-carrying coils in magnetic fields experience forces that produce rotation.
example_tasks: Explain the basic principle of motors: magnetic fields exert forces on current-carrying wires, causing rotation
Describe the role of commutators in DC motors to reverse current direction and maintain continuous rotation
Build a simple motor using wire coils, magnets, and a battery to demonstrate energy conversion
Identify everyday applications of electric motors: fans, power tools, electric vehicles, appliances

sub_topics.name: Electric Generators
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how rotating coils in magnetic fields induce alternating current through electromagnetic induction.
example_tasks: Explain how generators are essentially motors in reverse, converting mechanical to electrical energy
Describe the role of rotating coils in magnetic fields producing induced voltage through changing magnetic flux
Compare AC generators (alternators) that produce alternating current to DC generators with commutators
Trace energy transformations in power plants from fuel/falling water to mechanical rotation to electrical energy

sub_topics.name: Comparing Motors and Generators
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the symmetry between motors and generators as energy conversion devices.
example_tasks: Create a comparison table showing motors use electrical energy to produce mechanical motion while generators do the opposite
Explain how the same device can function as either motor or generator depending on whether you input electricity or mechanical rotation
Investigate regenerative braking in electric/hybrid vehicles that uses motors as generators to recover energy
Discuss the importance of electromagnetic induction and motor principles in modern electrical technology

sub_topics.name: Applications of Electromagnetism
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring practical devices and technologies that rely on electromagnetic principles.

sub_topics.name: Uses of Electromagnets
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying applications of electromagnets in everyday technology and industry.
example_tasks: Describe how electromagnets in scrapyards lift and release metal objects by controlling current
Explain how electric bells and buzzers use electromagnets to create vibrating motion and sound
Investigate magnetic levitation (maglev) trains that use electromagnets for levitation and propulsion
Research how MRI machines use powerful electromagnets to create detailed images of the body's interior

sub_topics.name: Speakers and Microphones
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how electromagnetic induction enables sound recording and reproduction.
example_tasks: Explain how speakers use electromagnets to convert electrical signals into sound through cone vibration
Describe how dynamic microphones use electromagnetic induction to convert sound vibrations into electrical signals
Compare the energy transformations in speakers (electrical to mechanical to sound) and microphones (sound to mechanical to electrical)
Investigate how headphones and earbuds use the same electromagnetic principles as speakers on a smaller scale

sub_topics.name: Relays and Solenoids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding electromagnetic switches and linear actuators used in control systems.
example_tasks: Explain how relays use small currents to control larger currents through electromagnetic switching
Describe solenoids as electromagnets that produce linear motion when energized, used in door locks and valves
Investigate applications of relays in automotive systems to control high-current devices like starter motors
Design a simple relay circuit that uses a low-voltage switch to control a high-voltage device safely

name: Thermal Energy and Heat Transfer
short_description: Students investigate thermal energy, temperature, heat transfer mechanisms, and the relationship between thermal energy and particle motion in matter.

sub_topics.name: Temperature and Thermal Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the distinction between temperature and thermal energy and how they relate to particle motion.

sub_topics.name: Kinetic Theory and Temperature
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding temperature as a measure of average kinetic energy of particles in a substance.
example_tasks: Explain temperature as the average kinetic energy of particles, with higher temperatures indicating faster-moving particles
Compare particle motion in hot versus cold substances using molecular models or simulations
Describe the relationship between temperature and particle speed in solids, liquids, and gases
Investigate how temperature affects the rate of diffusion, with higher temperatures causing faster spreading

sub_topics.name: Temperature Scales
sub_topics.short_description: Using Celsius, Fahrenheit, and Kelvin temperature scales and converting between them.
example_tasks: Convert temperatures between Celsius and Fahrenheit using the formulas F = (9/5)C + 32 and C = (5/9)(F - 32)
Explain the Kelvin scale starting at absolute zero (0 K = -273.15°C), the lowest possible temperature where particle motion ceases
Convert between Celsius and Kelvin using K = C + 273.15, noting that the degree size is the same
Compare the reference points for each scale: water freezes at 0°C, 32°F, 273 K and boils at 100°C, 212°F, 373 K

sub_topics.name: Thermal Energy versus Temperature
sub_topics.short_description: Distinguishing between thermal energy (total kinetic energy of all particles) and temperature (average kinetic energy per particle).
example_tasks: Explain why a large container of lukewarm water has more thermal energy than a small cup of hot water despite lower temperature
Compare thermal energy in objects of different masses at the same temperature, showing that more particles mean more total energy
Predict which object will cause more temperature change when placed in cool water: large warm object or small hot object
Describe how both temperature and amount of matter determine total thermal energy in a system

sub_topics.name: Measuring Temperature
sub_topics.short_description: Using thermometers and understanding how different types measure temperature through thermal expansion or other properties.
example_tasks: Explain how liquid thermometers work using thermal expansion of liquids (mercury or alcohol) in a narrow tube
Use various thermometer types (liquid, digital, infrared) to measure temperatures and compare readings
Describe how thermocouple thermometers measure temperature through voltage generated at junctions of different metals
Investigate proper thermometer use including equilibration time and placement to ensure accurate readings

sub_topics.name: Heat and Heat Transfer
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heat as energy transfer due to temperature difference and the three mechanisms of heat transfer.

sub_topics.name: Heat as Energy Transfer
sub_topics.short_description: Defining heat as thermal energy flowing from higher temperature to lower temperature objects until thermal equilibrium.
example_tasks: Explain that heat is energy in transit between objects at different temperatures, not a property stored in objects
Describe thermal equilibrium as the state where objects reach the same temperature and heat flow stops
Predict the direction of heat flow between objects of different temperatures (always from hot to cold)
Measure temperature changes when hot and cold water are mixed, demonstrating energy transfer to equilibrium

sub_topics.name: Conduction
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heat transfer through direct contact as particles collide and transfer kinetic energy.
example_tasks: Demonstrate conduction by heating one end of a metal rod and observing temperature increase along its length
Explain conduction at the particle level: fast-moving particles collide with slower ones, transferring energy
Compare thermal conductors (metals like copper and aluminum) to thermal insulators (wood, plastic, air)
Investigate why metals feel colder than wood at room temperature due to better heat conduction away from your hand

sub_topics.name: Convection
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heat transfer in fluids through the movement of heated material itself.
example_tasks: Observe convection currents in water heated from below, with warm water rising and cool water sinking
Explain convection as the circulation of fluid caused by density differences: warm fluid is less dense and rises
Describe convection's role in atmospheric circulation, ocean currents, and weather patterns
Investigate home heating systems that use convection to circulate warm air throughout rooms

sub_topics.name: Radiation (Thermal Radiation)
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding heat transfer through electromagnetic waves without requiring a medium.
example_tasks: Explain how the Sun heats Earth through radiation traveling through the vacuum of space as infrared waves
Demonstrate radiation by feeling warmth from a heat lamp or campfire without direct contact or air movement
Describe how all objects emit thermal radiation, with hotter objects emitting more and at shorter wavelengths
Investigate why dark surfaces absorb and emit radiation better than light, shiny surfaces that reflect it

sub_topics.name: Comparing Heat Transfer Methods
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing situations involving multiple heat transfer mechanisms and their relative effectiveness.
example_tasks: Identify which heat transfer mechanisms are involved in everyday situations (cooking, home heating, thermos bottles)
Explain how thermos bottles minimize heat transfer by using vacuum (prevents conduction/convection) and reflective surfaces (reduces radiation)
Compare the speed of heat transfer by conduction in metals versus insulators through simple experiments
Design an insulated container that minimizes all three heat transfer methods to keep liquids hot or cold

sub_topics.name: Specific Heat Capacity
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how different materials require different amounts of energy to change temperature.

sub_topics.name: Concept of Specific Heat
sub_topics.short_description: Defining specific heat as the amount of energy needed to raise the temperature of 1 kg of a substance by 1°C.
example_tasks: Explain that water has a high specific heat (4,186 J/kg·°C), meaning it requires much energy to change its temperature
Compare specific heats of different materials: water (high), metals (low), explaining why metals heat and cool quickly
Describe how high specific heat makes water useful for cooling systems and moderating climate near large bodies of water
Predict which of two materials will heat up faster when given the same energy based on specific heat values

sub_topics.name: Calculating Heat Transfer
sub_topics.short_description: Using the equation Q = mcΔT to calculate energy transferred during temperature changes.
example_tasks: Calculate the heat needed to raise 2 kg of water from 20°C to 100°C using Q = mcΔT where c = 4,186 J/kg·°C
Determine the final temperature when known amounts of heat energy are added to or removed from substances
Solve problems involving heat exchange between substances, using energy conservation (heat lost = heat gained)
Calculate specific heat of unknown materials by measuring temperature changes when known energy is added

sub_topics.name: Calorimetry and Heat Measurement
sub_topics.short_description: Using calorimeters to measure heat transfer and determine specific heats experimentally.
example_tasks: Describe how calorimeters are insulated containers used to measure heat exchange with minimal energy loss to surroundings
Conduct experiments mixing hot and cold water in a calorimeter to verify energy conservation (Q_lost = Q_gained)
Calculate the specific heat of a metal by heating it and placing it in cool water, measuring temperature changes
Explain the importance of insulation in calorimetry to ensure accurate measurements by preventing heat loss

sub_topics.name: Phase Changes and Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how energy is absorbed or released during changes of state without temperature change.

sub_topics.name: Phase Changes Between States
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying the six phase changes and understanding energy changes during transitions.
example_tasks: Name and describe the six phase changes: melting, freezing, vaporization, condensation, sublimation, deposition
Explain why temperature remains constant during phase changes despite continuous energy addition or removal
Describe energy absorption during melting/vaporization (endothermic) and energy release during freezing/condensation (exothermic)
Use heating/cooling curves to identify when a substance is changing phase (flat regions) versus changing temperature (sloped regions)

sub_topics.name: Heat of Fusion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the energy required to change between solid and liquid phases at constant temperature.
example_tasks: Define heat of fusion as the energy needed to melt 1 kg of a substance at its melting point (or released when freezing)
Calculate energy required to melt ice using Q = mL_f where L_f (heat of fusion for water) = 334,000 J/kg
Explain why ice at 0°C is more effective at cooling drinks than water at 0°C due to energy absorbed during melting
Compare heats of fusion for different substances and relate to the strength of intermolecular forces

sub_topics.name: Heat of Vaporization
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the energy required to change between liquid and gas phases at constant temperature.
example_tasks: Define heat of vaporization as energy needed to vaporize 1 kg of liquid at its boiling point (or released during condensation)
Calculate energy required to boil water using Q = mL_v where L_v (heat of vaporization for water) = 2,260,000 J/kg
Explain why steam burns are more severe than hot water burns due to energy released during condensation on skin
Compare heats of vaporization to heats of fusion, noting that vaporization requires much more energy

sub_topics.name: Evaporation and Cooling
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding evaporation as vaporization below boiling point and its cooling effect.
example_tasks: Explain evaporation as surface molecules with highest kinetic energy escaping the liquid, leaving cooler molecules behind
Describe how sweating cools the body through evaporative cooling as water absorbs heat from skin to evaporate
Investigate factors affecting evaporation rate: temperature, surface area, air movement, humidity
Demonstrate evaporative cooling by measuring temperature drop of water in a wet cloth versus dry cloth in moving air

sub_topics.name: Thermal Expansion
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how materials expand when heated and contract when cooled due to increased particle motion.

sub_topics.name: Thermal Expansion in Solids
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how solids expand in length, area, and volume when temperature increases.
example_tasks: Demonstrate thermal expansion by showing how a heated metal ball no longer fits through a ring it passed through when cool
Explain expansion at the particle level: increased temperature causes particles to vibrate more, increasing average separation
Describe practical applications: expansion joints in bridges, gaps in railroad tracks, bimetallic strips in thermostats
Investigate why different materials have different expansion rates (expansion coefficients)

sub_topics.name: Thermal Expansion in Liquids and Gases
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that liquids and gases generally expand more than solids when heated.
example_tasks: Explain how liquid thermometers work based on the expansion of liquids (mercury or alcohol) with temperature increase
Describe the anomalous expansion of water: it expands when cooling from 4°C to 0°C, which is why ice floats
Investigate gas expansion using balloons or containers, showing gases expand significantly with temperature
Apply Charles's Law qualitatively: gas volume increases proportionally with temperature at constant pressure

sub_topics.name: Problems and Solutions Related to Expansion
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing engineering problems caused by thermal expansion and design solutions to accommodate it.
example_tasks: Explain why bridges have expansion joints to allow for expansion on hot days without buckling
Describe why power lines sag more in summer than winter due to thermal expansion of the metal cables
Investigate why glass containers can crack when filled with very hot or very cold liquids (thermal shock)
Design solutions to thermal expansion problems: using materials with low expansion, adding gaps, using flexible joints

name: Engineering Design Process
short_description: Students apply the engineering design process to define problems, develop solutions, optimize designs, and test prototypes using scientific principles.

sub_topics.name: Defining Engineering Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Identifying problems, specifying criteria for success, and defining constraints that limit solutions.

sub_topics.name: Identifying and Analyzing Problems
sub_topics.short_description: Recognizing needs, understanding the problem context, and gathering relevant information.
example_tasks: Identify a real-world problem that could be solved through engineering (improving insulation, designing a water filter, creating a safety device)
Gather information about the problem through research, interviews, observations, or surveys
Analyze the root causes of the problem rather than just the symptoms that are immediately visible
Document the problem clearly, including who is affected and what impacts it has

sub_topics.name: Criteria and Constraints
sub_topics.short_description: Defining success criteria (what the solution must accomplish) and constraints (limitations on the solution).
example_tasks: List specific, measurable criteria for a successful solution (must support 5 kg, must cost under $10, must fit in 20 cm space)
Identify constraints that limit possible solutions: time, materials available, cost, size, safety requirements, environmental impact
Prioritize criteria by importance: which are essential (must have) versus which are desirable (nice to have)
Explain how criteria and constraints guide the design process and help evaluate potential solutions

sub_topics.name: Developing Possible Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Brainstorming multiple solutions, applying scientific principles, and selecting promising designs.

sub_topics.name: Brainstorming and Generating Ideas
sub_topics.short_description: Creating multiple possible solutions without judgment, then evaluating their potential.
example_tasks: Generate at least 3-5 different solution ideas for a problem through sketching, listing, or mind-mapping
Apply brainstorming rules: defer judgment, encourage wild ideas, build on others' ideas, aim for quantity
Sketch or describe each potential solution clearly enough for others to understand
Explain how diverse team members can contribute different perspectives and ideas to brainstorming

sub_topics.name: Applying Scientific Principles
sub_topics.short_description: Using physics concepts (forces, energy, electricity, heat) to develop and improve design solutions.
example_tasks: Apply Newton's laws to design a structure that can withstand specific forces without collapsing
Use energy conservation principles to design a device that efficiently converts one energy form to another
Apply heat transfer concepts to design insulation that minimizes thermal energy loss
Use circuit principles to design an electrical system that safely delivers power to components

sub_topics.name: Evaluating and Selecting Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing potential solutions against criteria and constraints to select the most promising design.
example_tasks: Create a decision matrix comparing each solution against the established criteria and constraints
Score each solution based on how well it meets criteria (1-5 scale) and whether it satisfies constraints
Justify the selection of one or two solutions to prototype based on evaluation results
Identify potential weaknesses in selected solutions that should be addressed during development

sub_topics.name: Testing and Optimizing Designs
sub_topics.short_description: Building prototypes, conducting tests, collecting data, and iteratively improving designs based on results.

sub_topics.name: Building Prototypes
sub_topics.short_description: Creating physical models or prototypes to test design concepts before final production.
example_tasks: Build a prototype using available materials that represents the key features of the design solution
Explain the purpose of prototyping: testing ideas quickly and cheaply before investing in final products
Compare rapid prototyping (simple, quick models) to refined prototypes (closer to final product)
Document the prototype construction process with sketches, photos, or step-by-step descriptions

sub_topics.name: Testing and Collecting Data
sub_topics.short_description: Conducting systematic tests to evaluate how well the prototype meets criteria and identifying failures.
example_tasks: Design fair tests that measure specific criteria (load capacity, insulation effectiveness, circuit voltage)
Collect quantitative data during testing using appropriate measuring tools (rulers, scales, thermometers, multimeters)
Conduct multiple trials to ensure results are reliable and identify inconsistencies
Document both successful performance and failures, noting what went wrong and why

sub_topics.name: Analyzing Test Results
sub_topics.short_description: Interpreting data to determine if the design meets criteria and identifying areas for improvement.
example_tasks: Compare test results to success criteria, determining which criteria were met and which were not
Analyze failure modes: identify what failed, when it failed, and what caused the failure
Use graphs or tables to display test data clearly and identify patterns or trends
Explain how scientific principles account for observed results (why the design worked or failed)

sub_topics.name: Iterative Design and Optimization
sub_topics.short_description: Using test results to make design improvements and repeating the test-analyze-improve cycle.
example_tasks: Identify specific design modifications to address failures or improve performance based on test results
Explain the iterative nature of engineering: design-build-test-improve cycle repeated multiple times
Compare performance of original prototype to improved versions, showing measurable improvements
Determine when a design is 'good enough' by evaluating whether it meets all essential criteria within constraints

sub_topics.name: Communicating Design Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Presenting design solutions through drawings, models, written reports, and oral presentations.

sub_topics.name: Technical Drawings and Diagrams
sub_topics.short_description: Creating clear drawings with labels and dimensions to communicate design details.
example_tasks: Draw labeled diagrams showing all components of the design with dimensions and materials specified
Use multiple views (top, front, side) to fully represent three-dimensional objects
Include a scale or dimensions on drawings so others can accurately reproduce the design
Create exploded view diagrams showing how components fit together in assemblies

sub_topics.name: Written Design Reports
sub_topics.short_description: Documenting the design process, testing results, and conclusions in written format.
example_tasks: Write a design report including: problem statement, criteria/constraints, solutions considered, chosen design, testing procedures, results, conclusions
Present data in appropriate formats: tables for raw data, graphs for showing relationships or comparisons
Explain the reasoning behind design decisions, referencing scientific principles where applicable
Include recommendations for future improvements or additional testing based on current results

sub_topics.name: Oral Presentations and Demonstrations
sub_topics.short_description: Effectively presenting design solutions to audiences through organized talks and demonstrations.
example_tasks: Prepare a presentation that includes problem definition, design solution, testing process, and results
Demonstrate the prototype in action, highlighting key features and explaining how it meets criteria
Use visual aids (posters, slides, models) to support verbal explanations
Respond to questions about design choices, testing methods, and potential improvements

sub_topics.name: Engineering Practices and Considerations
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding broader aspects of engineering including teamwork, ethics, sustainability, and real-world applications.

sub_topics.name: Teamwork and Collaboration
sub_topics.short_description: Working effectively in teams with diverse skills and perspectives to solve engineering problems.
example_tasks: Identify different roles team members can play in engineering projects (researcher, designer, builder, tester, presenter)
Practice effective communication within teams: active listening, clear explanations, constructive feedback
Resolve disagreements through evidence-based discussion and compromise
Explain how diverse teams bring different perspectives and expertise that lead to better solutions

sub_topics.name: Learning from Failure
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that failure is a valuable part of engineering, providing information for improvement.
example_tasks: Analyze famous engineering failures (bridge collapses, product recalls) to understand what went wrong and lessons learned
Explain how failure during testing is preferable to failure after deployment, allowing for improvements
Document failures systematically: what failed, under what conditions, possible causes, proposed fixes
Describe how engineers use failure analysis to improve designs and prevent future problems

sub_topics.name: Sustainability and Environmental Impact
sub_topics.short_description: Considering environmental impacts, resource use, and long-term sustainability in engineering designs.
example_tasks: Evaluate designs based on environmental criteria: material sustainability, energy efficiency, recyclability, lifetime impact
Compare renewable versus non-renewable materials and energy sources in design choices
Analyze life cycle impacts: production, use, and disposal/recycling of engineered products
Propose modifications to existing designs to improve sustainability (reduce energy use, use recycled materials, improve longevity)

sub_topics.name: Ethics and Safety in Engineering
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding ethical responsibilities and safety considerations in engineering practice.
example_tasks: Identify safety hazards in designs and propose safety features to protect users
Discuss ethical considerations: who benefits from the design, who might be harmed, is it accessible to all who need it
Explain engineers' responsibility to prioritize public safety over cost or convenience
Research case studies where ethical considerations played important roles in engineering decisions

name: Energy in Chemical Processes and Everyday Life
short_description: Students explore energy changes in chemical reactions, including exothermic and endothermic processes, and analyze energy transformations in everyday systems.

sub_topics.name: Energy Changes in Chemical Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that chemical reactions involve energy changes as bonds are broken and formed.

sub_topics.name: Chemical Bonds and Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that energy is required to break bonds and released when bonds form.
example_tasks: Explain that breaking chemical bonds requires energy input (endothermic process) while forming bonds releases energy (exothermic process)
Describe how the difference between energy needed to break bonds and energy released forming bonds determines if a reaction releases or absorbs energy overall
Diagram energy changes during a reaction showing bonds breaking in reactants and new bonds forming in products
Compare strong bonds (require more energy to break) to weak bonds (require less energy to break)

sub_topics.name: Exothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reactions that release energy to surroundings, usually as heat and sometimes light.
example_tasks: Identify exothermic reactions: combustion, many oxidation reactions, neutralization reactions, crystallization
Conduct exothermic reaction experiments (hand warmers, neutralizing acid and base) and measure temperature increases
Explain why exothermic reactions release energy: more energy released forming product bonds than absorbed breaking reactant bonds
Describe applications of exothermic reactions: heating, cooking, engines, explosives, hand warmers

sub_topics.name: Endothermic Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding reactions that absorb energy from surroundings, causing temperature decreases.
example_tasks: Identify endothermic reactions: photosynthesis, thermal decomposition, dissolving some salts (ammonium nitrate in water)
Conduct endothermic reaction experiments (instant cold packs) and measure temperature decreases
Explain why endothermic reactions absorb energy: more energy needed to break reactant bonds than released forming product bonds
Describe applications of endothermic reactions: cold packs, refrigeration, photosynthesis storing solar energy

sub_topics.name: Activation Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding that reactions require initial energy input (activation energy) to break bonds and get started.
example_tasks: Explain activation energy as the minimum energy needed to start a chemical reaction by breaking initial bonds
Use energy diagrams to show activation energy as the 'hill' that must be overcome for reactions to proceed
Describe how catalysts lower activation energy, allowing reactions to proceed faster at lower temperatures
Give examples of activation energy: striking a match, lighting a Bunsen burner, spark plugs in engines

sub_topics.name: Combustion Reactions
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding combustion as exothermic reactions with oxygen that release energy for heating and power.

sub_topics.name: Combustion Reactions and Products
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding combustion as rapid reaction with oxygen producing heat, light, and specific products.
example_tasks: Write word equations for combustion reactions: fuel + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water + energy
Identify requirements for combustion: fuel, oxygen, and activation energy (ignition temperature)
Explain complete combustion (sufficient oxygen) versus incomplete combustion (limited oxygen producing carbon monoxide or soot)
Test combustion products by collecting gases and testing with limewater (CO₂) or cobalt chloride paper (water)

sub_topics.name: Fuels and Energy Release
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing energy content of different fuels and understanding factors affecting energy release.
example_tasks: Compare energy density of different fuels (wood, coal, natural gas, gasoline) in terms of energy released per unit mass
Explain why hydrocarbons (molecules containing only carbon and hydrogen) make good fuels due to high energy content
Calculate energy released during combustion of known fuel masses using calorimetry experiments
Discuss renewable versus non-renewable fuels and environmental impacts of combustion

sub_topics.name: Fire Triangle and Fire Safety
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding the fire triangle (fuel, oxygen, heat) and methods to extinguish fires by removing one element.
example_tasks: Explain the fire triangle: combustion requires fuel, oxygen, and heat (activation energy)
Describe fire extinguishing methods: removing fuel, excluding oxygen (smothering), cooling below ignition temperature
Identify appropriate fire extinguishers for different fire types (water for wood/paper, CO₂ for electrical, foam for oil)
Analyze fire safety in buildings: smoke detectors, sprinklers, fire doors, evacuation routes

sub_topics.name: Energy Transformations in Systems
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing how energy is transformed and transferred in complex systems including vehicles, power plants, and living organisms.

sub_topics.name: Energy Transformations in Vehicles
sub_topics.short_description: Tracing energy conversions in cars, bicycles, and other transportation devices.
example_tasks: Trace energy transformations in gasoline cars: chemical energy (fuel) → thermal energy (combustion) → kinetic energy (motion)
Compare energy efficiency of different vehicles, explaining where energy is 'lost' as waste heat and friction
Analyze energy transformations in electric vehicles: chemical (battery) → electrical → kinetic (motor)
Calculate the efficiency of a vehicle engine by comparing useful kinetic energy output to total chemical energy input

sub_topics.name: Energy in Power Plants
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how power plants convert various energy sources into electrical energy.
example_tasks: Trace energy transformations in coal power plants: chemical (coal) → thermal (combustion) → kinetic (steam turbine) → electrical (generator)
Compare different power plant types: fossil fuel, nuclear, hydroelectric, wind, solar, in terms of energy conversions
Explain why power plants are typically only 30-40% efficient, with most energy lost as waste heat
Diagram the complete energy flow from fuel source through transmission lines to end users

sub_topics.name: Energy in Living Organisms
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding how organisms obtain, transform, and use energy for life processes.
example_tasks: Explain photosynthesis as endothermic conversion of light energy to chemical energy stored in glucose
Describe cellular respiration as exothermic conversion of chemical energy (food) to ATP for cellular work
Trace energy flow in ecosystems from sunlight → producers → consumers → decomposers
Calculate the energy efficiency of human bodies in converting food energy to useful work versus waste heat

sub_topics.name: Energy Use in the Home
sub_topics.short_description: Analyzing energy transformations and consumption in household appliances and systems.
example_tasks: Identify energy transformations in common appliances: toaster (electrical → thermal), TV (electrical → light + sound), fan (electrical → kinetic)
Calculate energy consumption of household devices using power ratings and usage time (kWh = kW × hours)
Evaluate home energy efficiency: insulation, LED vs incandescent bulbs, Energy Star appliances
Propose energy conservation strategies for homes based on understanding of energy transformations and waste

sub_topics.name: Renewable and Non-Renewable Energy Sources
sub_topics.short_description: Comparing different energy sources based on renewability, environmental impact, and sustainability.

sub_topics.name: Fossil Fuels
sub_topics.short_description: Understanding formation, uses, and environmental impacts of coal, oil, and natural gas.
example_tasks: Explain how fossil fuels formed from ancient organic matter over millions of years, making them non-renewable
Compare advantages (high energy density, established infrastructure) and disadvantages (pollution, climate change, finite supply) of fossil fuels
Analyze the carbon cycle and how burning fossil fuels increases atmospheric CO₂ concentrations
Calculate carbon footprints of different activities based on fossil fuel consumption

sub_topics.name: Renewable Energy Sources
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass energy as sustainable alternatives.
example_tasks: Compare renewable energy sources: solar (radiant → electrical), wind (kinetic → electrical), hydroelectric (gravitational potential → kinetic → electrical)
Explain advantages of renewables: sustainable, cleaner, reduce greenhouse gases; and challenges: intermittency, initial costs, location-dependent
Analyze energy transformations in solar panels (photovoltaic cells converting light directly to electricity)
Research local renewable energy projects and their contributions to regional energy needs

sub_topics.name: Nuclear Energy
sub_topics.short_description: Introducing nuclear fission as an energy source with high energy density but unique challenges.
example_tasks: Explain at a basic level that nuclear fission splits atomic nuclei, releasing enormous amounts of energy from mass-energy conversion
Compare nuclear energy advantages (no greenhouse gases, high energy density) to disadvantages (radioactive waste, safety concerns, high costs)
Describe energy transformations in nuclear plants: nuclear → thermal → kinetic (steam) → electrical
Discuss the importance of safe nuclear waste storage and reactor containment systems

sub_topics.name: Future Energy Solutions
sub_topics.short_description: Exploring emerging technologies and the transition toward sustainable energy systems.
example_tasks: Research emerging energy technologies: fusion power, improved solar cells, advanced batteries, hydrogen fuel cells
Analyze the concept of energy portfolios: using multiple energy sources together for reliability and sustainability
Propose solutions for local energy challenges based on available resources, climate, and population needs
Debate the trade-offs between different energy sources considering environmental, economic, and social factors
